'payment' : 'system', message: i % 2 ? `Payment received #INV-10${i}` : `System maintenance ${i+1}h notice`, createdAt: new Date(Date.now() - i * 3600_000).toISOString(), read: i > 2 })); const navigationItems = [ { text: 'Dashboard', route: '/', selected: true, icon: 'home' }, { text: 'Invoices', route: '/invoices' }, { text: 'Customers', route: '/customers' }, { text: 'Reports', route: '/reports' } ]; const chartMeta = { currency: 'USD', granularity: ['Daily','Weekly','Monthly','Quarterly'] }; const revenueSeries = Array.from({ length: 12 }).map((_, i) => ({ date: new Date(2025, i, 1), value: 50000 + i * 3800 + (i%2?2500:-1500) })); const userGrowthSeries = Array.from({ length: 12 }).map((_, i) => ({ date: new Date(2025, i, 1), value: 800 + i * 120 })); const transactions = Array.from({ length: 25 }).map((_, i) => ({ id: i + 1, user: { name: `Customer ${i+1}`, avatarUrl: `https://i.pravatar.cc/40?img=${(i%10)+1}` }, amount: 49.99 + (i % 5) * 25, currency: 'USD', status: ['Paid','Pending','Failed','Refunded'][i % 4], method: ['Card','Bank','PayPal','Cash'][i % 4], createdAt: new Date(Date.now() - i * 86400_000), invoiceUrl: `https://example.com/invoices/INV-10${i}` })); const footerLinks = [ { text: 'Privacy', url: '#' }, { text: 'Terms', url: '#' }, { text: 'Status', url: '#' } ]; // Local state const [drawerExpanded, setDrawerExpanded] = React.useState(true); const [notifOpen, setNotifOpen] = React.useState(false); const notifAnchorRef = React.useRef(null); const [granularityIndex, setGranularityIndex] = React.useState(2); const [page, setPage] = React.useState({ skip: 0, take: 10, total: 250 }); const [density, setDensity] = React.useState('comfortable'); const [themeDark, setThemeDark] = React.useState(false); // Helpers const currencyFmt = new Intl.NumberFormat(undefined, { style: 'currency', currency: 'USD' }); const dateFmt = (d) => new Intl.DateTimeFormat(undefined, { dateStyle: 'medium', timeStyle: undefined }).format(d); // Header search mock const [searchQuery, setSearchQuery] = React.useState(''); const searchIndex = React.useMemo(() => ( ['Invoice INV-1042','User Jane Doe','User John Smith','Invoice INV-1099'] ), []); const filteredSearch = React.useMemo(() => searchIndex.filter((s) => s.toLowerCase().includes(searchQuery.toLowerCase())), [searchIndex, searchQuery]); return (

structure.description: Root app shell for SaaS dashboard. Provides grid-based layout with fixed header, collapsible sidebar, and scrollable main. Consumes global data: user, notifications, navigationItems, kpis, charts, transactions, quickActions, appSettings.
structure.mcpQuery: Show me Kendo UI StackLayout examples with different orientations, spacing, and responsive behavior. Include examples for common layout patterns and styling with Tailwind CSS classes. Provide complete implementation with all props.

Locked columns are the columns that are visible at all times while the user scrolls the component horizontally. - Syntax: ## Examples ### Example 1 ``` import * as React from 'react'; import { Grid, GridColumn } from '@progress/kendo-react-grid'; const sampleData = [ { id: 1, name: 'Alice', description: 'description 1' }, { id: 2, name: 'Bob', description: 'description 2' }, { id: 3, name: 'Charlie', description: 'description 3' } ]; export default function App() { return ( ); } ``` filter operationsMulti-column filteringSortingSingle column sortingMulti-column sortingPagingNoCustom PagerVirtualizationNumeric pager with drop-downColumn virtualizationRow virtualizationExportingCVS exportPDF exportExcel exportLoadingLoading indicatorGroupingNoPersisting group stateAggregates for grouped dataLocked groupColumn groups the same as multi-column headersRow groupsMaster-detail gridNoMaster-detail gridOtherPrintAccessibilityKeyboard navigationLocalization and globalizationStylingAdaptivenessClipboard copyClipboard pasteChart integrationContext menuOData supportDataSource Toolbar ToolsServer and hybrid data operationsNoSupport for server templatesServer actionsServer-side renderingServer-side filteringServer-side selectionServer-side filtering KendoReact Data Grid Custom ColumnPremium The React Grid can be enhanced with custom AI-powered custom columns that provide personalized insights, summaries, and explanations about individual Grid rows. By integrating the Inline AI Prompt component with Custom cells, you can create an interactive experience where users can ask natural language questions about specific data records and receive contextual AI-generated responses. Key Features The KendoReact Server Data Grid offers an extensive and continuously expanding set of built-in features that isn't limited by the list in this section. What makes the Grid truly exceptional is its flexibility—it allows you to seamlessly blend both server-side and client-side operations, adapting to your application's unique requirements. Data Operations ## Available ReactComponent enum values: ActionSheet, AIPrompt, Animation, AppBar, ArcGauge, AutoComplete, Avatar, Badge, Barcode, BottomNavigation, Breadcrumb, Button, ButtonGroup, Calendar, Card, Chart, ChartWizard, Chat, Checkbox, Chip, ChipList, ChunkProgressBar, CircularGauge, ColorGradient, ColorPalette, ColorPicker, ComboBox, ContextMenu, ConversationalUI, DataGrid, Grid, DataQuery, DateMath, DateInput, DatePicker, DateRangePicker, DateTimePicker, Dialog, Drag&Drop, Drawer, Drawing, DropDownButton, DropDownList, DropDownTree, Editor, Error, ExcelExport, ExpansionPanel, ExternalDropZone, FileSaver, FileManager, Filter, FlatColorPicker, FloatingActionButton, FloatingLabel, FontIcon, Form, Gantt, Gauge, General, GridLayout, Hint, InlineAIPrompt, Input, Label, LinearGauge, ListBox, ListView, Loader, Map, MaskedTextBox, Menu, MultiColumnComboBox, MultiSelect, MultiSelectTree, MultiViewCalendar, Notification, NumericTextBox, OrgChart, PageTemplates/BuildingBlocks, Pager, PanelBar, PDFProcessing, PDFViewer, PivotGrid, Popover, Popup, ProgressBar, QRCode, RadialGauge, RadioButton, RadioGroup, RangeSlider, Rating, Ripple, Sankey, Scheduler, ScrollView, Signature, Skeleton, Slider, Sortable, Sparkline, SpeechToTextButton, SplitButton, Splitter, Spreadsheet, StackLayout, Stepper, StockChart, SVGIcon, Switch, TabStrip, TaskBoard, TextArea, TextBox, TileLayout, Timeline, TimePicker, Toolbar, Tooltip, TreeList, TreeView, Typography, Upload, VSCodeExtension, Window ## Rules When generating code, explanations, or refactorings, always follow these rules: 1. Component Awareness Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component. Key points: - Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations - If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button) - After matching, use the example or information associated with that component - The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example. Gotcha: Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches. 2. Links Awareness When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to. Key points: - Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links - Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders - Ensure links are directly accessible and functional - Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs Example: ✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/ ❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview 3. Editor Tools Awareness For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools. Required pattern: ```jsx import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'; const { Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough, Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor, CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify, Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList, NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo, FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink, InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile, SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties, AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter, DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell } = EditorTools; ``` Key points: - Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' - Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object - Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array - Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic') - Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization Example: ✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]} ❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]} 4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used: Deprecated properties and their modern replacements: - selectedField → use the select state property - editField → use the edit state property - expandedField → use the detailExpand state property - onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion - cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop - filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop Additional modern updates: - Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox - scrollable prop now defaults to virtual - Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default Key points: - Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples - Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties - Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement - Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props Example: ❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit" ✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration

Component Awareness Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component. Key points: - Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations - If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button) - After matching, use the example or information associated with that component - The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example. Gotcha: Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches. 2. Links Awareness When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to. Key points: - Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links - Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders - Ensure links are directly accessible and functional - Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs Example: ✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/ ❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview 3. Editor Tools Awareness For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools. Required pattern: ```jsx import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'; const { Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough, Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor, CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify, Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList, NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo, FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink, InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile, SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties, AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter, DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell } = EditorTools; ``` Key points: - Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' - Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object - Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array - Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic') - Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization Example: ✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]} ❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]} 4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used: Deprecated properties and their modern replacements: - selectedField → use the select state property - editField → use the edit state property - expandedField → use the detailExpand state property - onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion - cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop - filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop Additional modern updates: - Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox - scrollable prop now defaults to virtual - Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default Key points: - Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples - Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties - Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement - Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props Example: ❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit" ✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration

The possible values are: * `base` —Applies coloring based on the `base` theme color. * `primary` (Default)—Applies coloring based on primary theme color. * `secondary` —Applies coloring based on secondary theme color. * `tertiary` — Applies coloring based on tertiary theme color. * `inherit` — Applies inherited coloring value. * `info` —Applies coloring based on info theme color. * `success` — Applies coloring based on success theme color. * `warning` — Applies coloring based on warning theme color. * `error` — Applies coloring based on error theme color. * `dark` — Applies coloring based on dark theme color. * `light` — Applies coloring based on light theme color. * `inverse` — Applies coloring based on inverse theme color. * null—Does not set a themeColor `className` . - Syntax: ## Examples ### Example 1 ``` import * as React from 'react'; import { Badge } from '@progress/kendo-react-indicators'; import { Button } from '@progress/kendo-react-buttons'; export default function App() { return ( ); } ``` KendoReact enables you to create a beautiful and fast Grid with live data. The Grid Live Data App uses one of the most powerful KendoReact components such as the KendoReact Chart, React Badge, Grid, and more. Appearance The Badge component provides many predefined appearance options such as different shapes, sizes, theme colors and optional cutout borders. Theme Color The Badge allows you to specify predefined theme colors. The available themeColor values are: The Badge component is a visual indicator for UI elements. It enables you to easily show statuses, notifications, and short messages in your app. Badges provide additional contextual information for other elements on the page. The available options are: - small - medium - large - null—Does not set a size `className` . - Syntax: ## Examples ### Example 1 ``` import * as React from 'react'; import { Avatar } from '@progress/kendo-react-layout'; export default function App() { return AB; } ``` To specify a custom avatar size, use the styleproperty. ExampleView SourceEdit inChange ThemeThemeDefaultLoading ... Fill Mode The Avatar enables you to set styling options and create solid or outline avatars by setting the fillMode property. The available fillMode values are: solid (Default) outline Key Features Appearance—The Avatar comes with predefined option that allow you to set its shape, type, color, size, border, and fill. The Avatar component is typically used to display images, icons, or initials representing people or other entities. Component Awareness Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component. Key points: - Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations - If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button) - After matching, use the example or information associated with that component - The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example. Gotcha: Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches. 2. Links Awareness When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to. Key points: - Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links - Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders - Ensure links are directly accessible and functional - Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs Example: ✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/ ❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview 3. Editor Tools Awareness For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools. Required pattern: ```jsx import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'; const { Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough, Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor, CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify, Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList, NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo, FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink, InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile, SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties, AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter, DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell } = EditorTools; ``` Key points: - Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' - Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object - Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array - Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic') - Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization Example: ✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]} ❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]} 4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used: Deprecated properties and their modern replacements: - selectedField → use the select state property - editField → use the edit state property - expandedField → use the detailExpand state property - onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion - cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop - filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop Additional modern updates: - Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox - scrollable prop now defaults to virtual - Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default Key points: - Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples - Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties - Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement - Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props Example: ❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit" ✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration

## Rules
When generating code, explanations, or refactorings, always follow these rules:

1. Component Awareness
Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component.


Key points:
- Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations
- If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button)
- After matching, use the example or information associated with that component
- The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations

Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example.

Gotcha:
Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches.

2. Links Awareness
When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to.

Key points:
- Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links
- Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders
- Ensure links are directly accessible and functional
- Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs

Example:
✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/
❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview

3. Editor Tools Awareness
For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools.

Required pattern:
```jsx
import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor';

const {
    Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough,
    Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor,
    CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify,
    Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList,
    NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo,
    FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink,
    InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile,
    SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties,
    AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter,
    DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell
} = EditorTools;
```

Key points:
- Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'
- Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object
- Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array
- Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic')
- Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization

Example:
✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]}
❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]}

4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness
For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used:

Deprecated properties and their modern replacements:
- selectedField → use the select state property
- editField → use the edit state property
- expandedField → use the detailExpand state property
- onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion
- cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop
- rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop
- filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop
- headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop
- column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop
- column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop
- column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop
- column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop

Additional modern updates:
- Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox
- scrollable prop now defaults to virtual
- Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default

Key points:
- Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples
- Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties
- Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement
- Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props

Example:
❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit"
✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration

## Examples
### Example 1
```
import * as React from 'react';
import { Chart, ChartSeries, ChartSeriesItem } from '@progress/kendo-react-charts';

export default function App() {
    return (
        <Chart>
            <ChartSeries>
                <ChartSeriesItem type="line" data={[1, 2, 3]} />
            </ChartSeries>
        </Chart>
    );
}

## API Reference Item
- Name: ChartTooltipProps.shared
- Type: Property
- Summary: If set to 
`true`
, the Chart displays a single tooltip for every category ([see example]({% slug tooltips_chart_charts %}#toc-shared-tooltip)).
- Syntax: 

## Examples
### Example 1
```
import * as React from 'react';

import { Chart, ChartSeries, ChartSeriesItem, ChartTooltip } from '@progress/kendo-react-charts';

const series = [2, 4, 6, 2];

const App = () => (
    <Chart>
        <ChartTooltip shared={true} />
        <ChartSeries>
            <ChartSeriesItem type="bar" data={series} />
            <ChartSeriesItem type="bar" data={series} />
        </ChartSeries>
    </Chart>
);

export default App;

```


## API Reference Item
- Name: ChartZoomable
- Type: Function
- Summary: Represents the KendoReact ChartZoomable component.
- Syntax: 

## Examples
### Example 1
```
import * as React from 'react';

import {
    Chart,
    ChartSeries,
    ChartSeriesItem,
    ChartCategoryAxis,
    ChartCategoryAxisTitle,
    ChartCategoryAxisItem,
    ChartZoomable
} from '@progress/kendo-react-charts';

const series = [2, 4, 6, 2];
const categories = ['Q1', 'Q2', 'Q3', 'Q4'];
const App = () => (
    <Chart>
        <ChartZoomable mousewheel={true} />
        <ChartCategoryAxis>
            <ChartCategoryAxisItem categories={categories}>
                <ChartCategoryAxisTitle text="Months" />
            </ChartCategoryAxisItem>
        </ChartCategoryAxis>
        <ChartSeries>
            <ChartSeriesItem type="bar" gap={2} spacing={0.25} data={series} />
        </ChartSeries>
    </Chart>
);

export default App;

```

## API Reference Item
- Name: ChartAxisDefaultsCrosshair
- Type: Function
- Summary: Represents the KendoReact ChartAxisDefaultsCrosshair component.
- Syntax: 

## Examples
### Example 1
```
import * as React from 'react';

import {
    Chart,
    ChartAxisDefaults,
    ChartAxisDefaultsCrosshair,
    ChartCategoryAxis,
    ChartCategoryAxisItem,
    ChartSeries,
    ChartSeriesItem
} from '@progress/kendo-react-charts';

const data = [1, 2, 3, 5];

const categories = ['Q1', 'Q2', 'Q3', 'Q4'];

const ChartContainer = () => (
    <Chart>
        <ChartAxisDefaults>
            <ChartAxisDefaultsCrosshair visible={true} />
        </ChartAxisDefaults>
        <ChartCategoryAxis>
            <ChartCategoryAxisItem categories={categories} />
        </ChartCategoryAxis>
        <ChartSeries>
            <ChartSeriesItem data={data} name="Fibonacci" />
        </ChartSeries>
    </Chart>
);

export default ChartContainer;

```

## Rules
When generating code, explanations, or refactorings, always follow these rules:

1. Component Awareness
Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component.


Key points:
- Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations
- If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button)
- After matching, use the example or information associated with that component
- The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations

Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example.

Gotcha:
Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches.

2. Links Awareness
When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to.

Key points:
- Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links
- Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders
- Ensure links are directly accessible and functional
- Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs

Example:
✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/
❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview

3. Editor Tools Awareness
For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools.

Required pattern:
```jsx
import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor';

const {
    Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough,
    Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor,
    CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify,
    Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList,
    NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo,
    FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink,
    InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile,
    SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties,
    AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter,
    DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell
} = EditorTools;
```

Key points:
- Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'
- Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object
- Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array
- Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic')
- Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization

Example:
✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]}
❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]}

4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness
For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used:

Deprecated properties and their modern replacements:
- selectedField → use the select state property
- editField → use the edit state property
- expandedField → use the detailExpand state property
- onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion
- cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop
- rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop
- filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop
- headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop
- column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop
- column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop
- column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop
- column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop

Additional modern updates:
- Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox
- scrollable prop now defaults to virtual
- Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default

Key points:
- Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples
- Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties
- Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement
- Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props

Example:
❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit"
✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration

mcpResponses.Pager:
Added the new size property that allows you to configure the size of the Pager and supports small, medium, large and not set size (null). Added k-grid-{size} class to the main wrapping element of the component. Necessary to introduce the Size options of the Grid. The child elements inherit the k-grid-{size} class. Added k-toolbar-{size} class to the wrapping element of the toolbar. Added a new
wrapper of the groups. This section looks at some of the premium Data Grid features. To be able to complete this part of the tutorial, you need a commercial license or an active trial license. Features like sorting, filtering, and paging require you to configure data operations. As the Grid in this tutorial is bound to local (client-side) data, enable local data operations by following these steps: Enable each data operation separately in the Grid declaration (pageable={true} and sortable={true}). The KendoReact Pager is part of the KendoReact library of React UI components. It is distributed through NPM under the kendo-react-data-tools package. You can configure the Pager by using the following properties: ## Available ReactComponent enum values: ActionSheet, AIPrompt, Animation, AppBar, ArcGauge, AutoComplete, Avatar, Badge, Barcode, BottomNavigation, Breadcrumb, Button, ButtonGroup, Calendar, Card, Chart, ChartWizard, Chat, Checkbox, Chip, ChipList, ChunkProgressBar, CircularGauge, ColorGradient, ColorPalette, ColorPicker, ComboBox, ContextMenu, ConversationalUI, DataGrid, Grid, DataQuery, DateMath, DateInput, DatePicker, DateRangePicker, DateTimePicker, Dialog, Drag&Drop, Drawer, Drawing, DropDownButton, DropDownList, DropDownTree, Editor, Error, ExcelExport, ExpansionPanel, ExternalDropZone, FileSaver, FileManager, Filter, FlatColorPicker, FloatingActionButton, FloatingLabel, FontIcon, Form, Gantt, Gauge, General, GridLayout, Hint, InlineAIPrompt, Input, Label, LinearGauge, ListBox, ListView, Loader, Map, MaskedTextBox, Menu, MultiColumnComboBox, MultiSelect, MultiSelectTree, MultiViewCalendar, Notification, NumericTextBox, OrgChart, PageTemplates/BuildingBlocks, Pager, PanelBar, PDFProcessing, PDFViewer, PivotGrid, Popover, Popup, ProgressBar, QRCode, RadialGauge, RadioButton, RadioGroup, RangeSlider, Rating, Ripple, Sankey, Scheduler, ScrollView, Signature, Skeleton, Slider, Sortable, Sparkline, SpeechToTextButton, SplitButton, Splitter, Spreadsheet, StackLayout, Stepper, StockChart, SVGIcon, Switch, TabStrip, TaskBoard, TextArea, TextBox, TileLayout, Timeline, TimePicker, Toolbar, Tooltip, TreeList, TreeView, Typography, Upload, VSCodeExtension, Window ## Rules When generating code, explanations, or refactorings, always follow these rules: 1. Component Awareness Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component. Key points: - Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations - If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button) - After matching, use the example or information associated with that component - The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example. Gotcha: Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches. 2. Links Awareness When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to. Key points: - Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links - Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders - Ensure links are directly accessible and functional - Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs Example: ✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/ ❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview 3. Editor Tools Awareness For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools. Required pattern: ```jsx import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'; const { Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough, Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor, CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify, Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList, NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo, FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink, InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile, SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties, AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter, DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell } = EditorTools; ``` Key points: - Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' - Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object - Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array - Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic') - Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization Example: ✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]} ❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]} 4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used: Deprecated properties and their modern replacements: - selectedField → use the select state property - editField → use the edit state property - expandedField → use the detailExpand state property - onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion - cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop - filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop Additional modern updates: - Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox - scrollable prop now defaults to virtual - Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default Key points: - Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples - Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties - Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement - Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props Example: ❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit" ✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration
mcpResponses.Button: ## API Reference Item - Name: ButtonProps - Type: Interface - Summary: Represents the props of the [KendoReact Button component]({% slug overview_button %}). Extends the [native button props](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLButtonElement). - Syntax: ## Additional Context ### ButtonProps.endIcon (children) name: endIcon fullName: ButtonProps.endIcon summary: "Sets an SVG icon or custom element after the content of the Button. For the custom component, consider using\r\n[Phrasing content](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Content_categories#phrasing_content).\r\nDo not use [Interactive content](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Content_categories#interactive_content)." syntax: return: type: ReactNode packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.fillMode (children) name: fillMode fullName: ButtonProps.fillMode summary: |- Configures the `fillMode` of the Button. See [Button Appearance](slug://appearance_button). syntax: return: type: null | "flat" | "solid" | "outline" | "link" | "clear" packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.icon (children) name: icon fullName: ButtonProps.icon summary: >- Defines the name for an existing icon in a KendoReact theme ([see example]({% slug icons_button %})). The icon renders inside the Button by a `span.k-icon` element. syntax: return: type: string packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.iconClass (children) name: iconClass fullName: ButtonProps.iconClass summary: >- Defines a CSS class — or multiple classes separated by spaces — which apply to a `span` element inside the Button ([see example]({% slug icons_button %})). Allows you to use custom icons. syntax: return: type: string packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.iconSize (children) name: iconSize fullName: ButtonProps.iconSize summary: |- Configures the `size` of the SVG icon that displays inside the Button. syntax: return: type: null | "small" | "medium" | "large" packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.imageAlt (children) name: imageAlt fullName: ButtonProps.imageAlt summary: >- Defines the alternative text of the image that renders inside the Button component. syntax: return: type: string packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.imageUrl (children) name: imageUrl fullName: ButtonProps.imageUrl summary: |- Defines a URL which is used as an `img` element inside the Button ([see example]({% slug icons_button %})). The URL can be relative or absolute. If relative, it evaluates in relation to the URL of the web page. syntax: return: type: string packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.rounded (children) name: rounded fullName: ButtonProps.rounded summary: |- Configures the `roundness` of the Button. See [Button Appearance](slug://appearance_button). syntax: return: type: null | "small" | "medium" | "large" | "full" packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.selected (children) name: selected fullName: ButtonProps.selected summary: Sets the selected state of the Button. You can use this for controlled mode. syntax: return: type: boolean packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.size (children) name: size fullName: ButtonProps.size summary: |- Configures the `size` of the Button. See [Button Appearance](slug://appearance_button). syntax: return: type: null | "small" | "medium" | "large" packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.startIcon (children) name: startIcon fullName: ButtonProps.startIcon summary: "Sets an SVG icon or custom element before the content of the Button. For the custom component, consider using\r\n[Phrasing content](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Content_categories#phrasing_content).\r\nDo not use [Interactive content](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Content_categories#interactive_content)." syntax: return: type: ReactNode packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.svgIcon (children) name: svgIcon fullName: ButtonProps.svgIcon summary: Defines the SVG icon that renders inside the Button component. syntax: return: type: SVGIcon packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.themeColor (children) name: themeColor fullName: ButtonProps.themeColor summary: |- Configures the `themeColor` of the Button. See [Button Appearance](slug://appearance_button). syntax: return: type: >- null | "base" | "primary" | "secondary" | "tertiary" | "info" | "success" | "warning" | "error" | "dark" | "light" | "inverse" packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.title (children) name: title fullName: ButtonProps.title summary: |- Sets the `title` HTML attribute of the Button. syntax: return: type: string packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.togglable (children) name: togglable fullName: ButtonProps.togglable summary: >- Provides visual styling that shows if the Button is selected ([see example]({% slug toggleable_button %})). syntax: return: type: boolean packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' --- ### ButtonProps.unstyled (children) name: unstyled fullName: ButtonProps.unstyled summary: The unstyled option classes. syntax: return: type: ButtonsClassStructure packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-buttons' ## API Reference Item - Name: ButtonProps.disabled - Type: Property - Summary: Specifies if the Button is disabled ([see example]({% slug disabled_button %})). - Syntax: ## Examples ### Example 1 ``` import * as React from 'react'; import { Button } from '@progress/kendo-react-buttons'; const App = () => { return ( ); } export default App; ``` Button Events The KendoReact Button generates a variety of events that you can handle. This allows you to tailor the Button's behavior to your specific requirements. The following example demonstrates basic Button events. ExampleView SourceEdit inChange ThemeThemeDefaultLoading ... Out of the box, the Kendo React Button provides extensive accessibility support and enables users with disabilities to acquire complete control over its features. Add buttons to your Grid header or rows. Use buttons to submit data with Inputs. Build more interactive Dialogs with buttons. syntax: {} packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-form' members: - ignoreModified - initialValues - onSubmit - onSubmitClick - render - validator We use form validation to make sure that users provide correct information in terms of format, content length, etc. For example, is the phone number an actual number, did the user put info in all of the required fields, and so on. How it Works? KendoReact supports handling user input in the UI, and displays useful validation messages using the Form, Field, and Error components. Refer to the article on form validation for further details and runnable demos. Field-level Form Validation The Field component and its FieldRenderProps enable you to control when and how validation messages are shown. Error Messages For instant validation, error messages are the best way to alert users that they have made a mistake while filling out a form. Applying only error-specific styles does not convey enough information about what the user should do to provide valid data. Error messages should specify exactly why the user input is not accepted. Error messages for different fields should appear one by one. KendoReact provides an Error component for that use. To associate it with the editor for screen readers, set the id property of the component to the ariaDescribedBy property of the editor. ## Available ReactComponent enum values: ActionSheet, AIPrompt, Animation, AppBar, ArcGauge, AutoComplete, Avatar, Badge, Barcode, BottomNavigation, Breadcrumb, Button, ButtonGroup, Calendar, Card, Chart, ChartWizard, Chat, Checkbox, Chip, ChipList, ChunkProgressBar, CircularGauge, ColorGradient, ColorPalette, ColorPicker, ComboBox, ContextMenu, ConversationalUI, DataGrid, Grid, DataQuery, DateMath, DateInput, DatePicker, DateRangePicker, DateTimePicker, Dialog, Drag&Drop, Drawer, Drawing, DropDownButton, DropDownList, DropDownTree, Editor, Error, ExcelExport, ExpansionPanel, ExternalDropZone, FileSaver, FileManager, Filter, FlatColorPicker, FloatingActionButton, FloatingLabel, FontIcon, Form, Gantt, Gauge, General, GridLayout, Hint, InlineAIPrompt, Input, Label, LinearGauge, ListBox, ListView, Loader, Map, MaskedTextBox, Menu, MultiColumnComboBox, MultiSelect, MultiSelectTree, MultiViewCalendar, Notification, NumericTextBox, OrgChart, PageTemplates/BuildingBlocks, Pager, PanelBar, PDFProcessing, PDFViewer, PivotGrid, Popover, Popup, ProgressBar, QRCode, RadialGauge, RadioButton, RadioGroup, RangeSlider, Rating, Ripple, Sankey, Scheduler, ScrollView, Signature, Skeleton, Slider, Sortable, Sparkline, SpeechToTextButton, SplitButton, Splitter, Spreadsheet, StackLayout, Stepper, StockChart, SVGIcon, Switch, TabStrip, TaskBoard, TextArea, TextBox, TileLayout, Timeline, TimePicker, Toolbar, Tooltip, TreeList, TreeView, Typography, Upload, VSCodeExtension, Window ## Rules When generating code, explanations, or refactorings, always follow these rules: 1. Component Awareness Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component. Key points: - Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations - If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button) - After matching, use the example or information associated with that component - The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example. Gotcha: Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches. 2. Links Awareness When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to. Key points: - Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links - Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders - Ensure links are directly accessible and functional - Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs Example: ✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/ ❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview 3. Editor Tools Awareness For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools. Required pattern: ```jsx import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'; const { Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough, Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor, CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify, Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList, NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo, FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink, InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile, SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties, AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter, DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell } = EditorTools; ``` Key points: - Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' - Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object - Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array - Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic') - Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization Example: ✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]} ❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]} 4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used: Deprecated properties and their modern replacements: - selectedField → use the select state property - editField → use the edit state property - expandedField → use the detailExpand state property - onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion - cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop - filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop Additional modern updates: - Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox - scrollable prop now defaults to virtual - Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default Key points: - Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples - Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties - Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement - Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props Example: ❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit" ✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration
mcpResponses.Toolbar: ## API Reference Item - Name: ToolbarProps.className - Type: Property - Summary: Sets additional classes to the Toolbar. - Syntax: ## Examples ### Example 1 ``` import * as React from 'react'; import { Toolbar, Button, ButtonGroup } from '@progress/kendo-react-buttons'; import { boldIcon, italicIcon, underlineIcon } from '@progress/kendo-svg-icons'; const App = () => { return ( ); } ``` Out of the box, the Kendo React ToolBar provides extensive accessibility support and enables users with disabilities to acquire complete control over its features. Tools—You can include various button types in the Toolbar and create a handy selection of tools. Adaptive Rendering—The ToolBar provides options to hide the tools that do not fit its width in an overflow section or rendering scroll arrows. The Toolbar is part of the KendoReact Buttons component library. The procedures for installing, importing, and using all components in the library are identical. To learn how to use the Toolbar and the rest of the components in the package, see the Getting Started with the KendoReact Buttons guide. To render a custom validation message, set the validationMessage prop. ExampleView SourceEdit inChange ThemeThemeDefaultLoading ... Enforcing the Validity State The NumericTextBox supports props for setting basic validation requirements—for example, the minimum and maximum value. The min, max, and required properties enable the user to pre-define minimum requirements which define the validity state of the component and allow a successful form Forms Support The NumericTextBox supports a native KendoReact implementation of HTML5 form validation. The forms supports enables you to validate input values and prevent the submission of forms which are in an invalid state. Item {item}
))} ); } export default App; ``` ## Additional Context ### StackLayoutProps (children) name: StackLayoutProps fullName: StackLayoutProps summary: >- Represents the props of the [KendoReact StackLayout component]({% slug overview_stacklayout %}). syntax: {} packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-layout' members: - align - children - className - gap - id - orientation - style --- ### StackLayout.StackLayout.props (children) name: props fullName: StackLayout.StackLayout.props syntax: return: type: StackLayoutProps | RefAttributes ## API Reference Item - Name: StackLayoutProps.gap - Type: Property - Summary: Specifies the gap between the inner elements ([see example]({% slug layout_stacklayout %}#toc-gaps)). - Syntax: ## Examples ### Example 1 ``` import * as React from 'react'; import { StackLayout } from '@progress/kendo-react-layout'; function App() { return ( {[1, 2, 3].map((item) => (
Item {item}
))} ); } export default App; ``` Layout The StackLayout component provides options for controlling its appearance. To customize the layout of the StackLayout, use any of the following configuration options: Orientation Gaps Horizontal alignment Vertical alignment Nested StackLayouts Orientation To set the StackLayout orientation, use the orientation property. By default, orientation is set to horizontal. ExampleView SourceEdit inChange ThemeThemeDefaultLoading ... Gaps Gaps To set the StackLayout gaps, use the gap property. By default, the StackLayout does not apply a gap. ExampleView SourceEdit inChange ThemeThemeDefaultLoading ... Horizontal alignment To set the StackLayout horizontal alignment, use the align property. The horizontal key controls the alignment of the inner elements based on the X axis. The available values are: Orientation—The orientation configuration option allows you to choose between the vertical and horizontal positioning. Gaps—The Gap property allows you to set gaps between the boxes. Horizontal alignment—You can align the StackLayout horizontally. ## Available ReactComponent enum values: ActionSheet, AIPrompt, Animation, AppBar, ArcGauge, AutoComplete, Avatar, Badge, Barcode, BottomNavigation, Breadcrumb, Button, ButtonGroup, Calendar, Card, Chart, ChartWizard, Chat, Checkbox, Chip, ChipList, ChunkProgressBar, CircularGauge, ColorGradient, ColorPalette, ColorPicker, ComboBox, ContextMenu, ConversationalUI, DataGrid, Grid, DataQuery, DateMath, DateInput, DatePicker, DateRangePicker, DateTimePicker, Dialog, Drag&Drop, Drawer, Drawing, DropDownButton, DropDownList, DropDownTree, Editor, Error, ExcelExport, ExpansionPanel, ExternalDropZone, FileSaver, FileManager, Filter, FlatColorPicker, FloatingActionButton, FloatingLabel, FontIcon, Form, Gantt, Gauge, General, GridLayout, Hint, InlineAIPrompt, Input, Label, LinearGauge, ListBox, ListView, Loader, Map, MaskedTextBox, Menu, MultiColumnComboBox, MultiSelect, MultiSelectTree, MultiViewCalendar, Notification, NumericTextBox, OrgChart, PageTemplates/BuildingBlocks, Pager, PanelBar, PDFProcessing, PDFViewer, PivotGrid, Popover, Popup, ProgressBar, QRCode, RadialGauge, RadioButton, RadioGroup, RangeSlider, Rating, Ripple, Sankey, Scheduler, ScrollView, Signature, Skeleton, Slider, Sortable, Sparkline, SpeechToTextButton, SplitButton, Splitter, Spreadsheet, StackLayout, Stepper, StockChart, SVGIcon, Switch, TabStrip, TaskBoard, TextArea, TextBox, TileLayout, Timeline, TimePicker, Toolbar, Tooltip, TreeList, TreeView, Typography, Upload, VSCodeExtension, Window ## Rules When generating code, explanations, or refactorings, always follow these rules: 1. Component Awareness Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component. Key points: - Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations - If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button) - After matching, use the example or information associated with that component - The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example. Gotcha: Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches. 2. Links Awareness When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to. Key points: - Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links - Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders - Ensure links are directly accessible and functional - Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs Example: ✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/ ❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview 3. Editor Tools Awareness For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools. Required pattern: ```jsx import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'; const { Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough, Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor, CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify, Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList, NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo, FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink, InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile, SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties, AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter, DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell } = EditorTools; ``` Key points: - Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' - Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object - Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array - Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic') - Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization Example: ✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]} ❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]} 4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used: Deprecated properties and their modern replacements: - selectedField → use the select state property - editField → use the edit state property - expandedField → use the detailExpand state property - onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion - cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop - filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop Additional modern updates: - Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox - scrollable prop now defaults to virtual - Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default Key points: - Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples - Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties - Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement - Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props Example: ❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit" ✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration

import { Sparkline } from '@progress/kendo-react-charts'; export default function App() { return ( ); } ``` Generally, Sparklines are simple, word-sized graphics that can be embedded in tables, headlines, or chunks of text. The concept for their graphical representation was developed by Edward Tufte. The KendoReact Sparkline is a version of the KendoReact Chart which is tailored for this specific application. While the standard KendoReact Chart component behaves like a block element, due to its rendering inside a div element to allow for an easy Key Features Sparklines include shortcuts for setting the data and type series options. The Sparkline also supports all configuration options that are applicable for the Categorical series type of the Chart. The Sparkline Chart is part of KendoReact premium, an enterprise-grade UI library with 120+ free and premium components for building polished, performant apps. Test-drive all features with a free 30-day trial.

If the data contains only primitive values, do not define it. syntax: return: type: string packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-dropdowns' --- ### AutoCompleteProps.valid (children) name: valid fullName: AutoCompleteProps.valid summary: "Overrides the validity state of the component.\r\nIf \n`valid`\n is set, the \n`required`\n property will be ignored.\r\n\r\nThis property is part of the [FormComponentProps]({% slug api_common_formcomponentprops %}) interface." syntax: return: type: boolean packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-common' --- ### AutoCompleteProps.validationMessage (children) name: validationMessage fullName: AutoCompleteProps.validationMessage summary: "Controls the form error message of the component. If set to an empty string, no error will be thrown.\r\n\r\nThis property is part of the [FormComponentProps]({% slug api_common_formcomponentprops %}) interface." syntax: return: type: string packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-common' --- ### AutoCompleteProps.validityStyles (children) name: validityStyles fullName: AutoCompleteProps.validityStyles summary: "If set to \n`false`\n, no visual representation of the invalid state of the component will be applied.\r\n\r\nThis property is part of the [FormComponentProps]({% slug api_common_formcomponentprops %}) interface." syntax: return: type: boolean packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-common' --- ### AutoCompleteProps.value (children) name: value fullName: AutoCompleteProps.value summary: >- Sets the value of the AutoComplete ([more information and example]({% slug binding_autocomplete %})). syntax: return: type: string packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-dropdowns' --- ### AutoCompleteProps.valueRender (children) name: valueRender fullName: AutoCompleteProps.valueRender summary: >- Fires when the AutoComplete input element is about to be rendered. Use it to override the default appearance of the component. syntax: return: type: >- (rendering: ReactElement>) => ReactNode packageName: '@progress/kendo-react-dropdowns' ## API Reference Item - Name: AutoCompleteProps.clearButton - Type: Property - Summary: By default, the AutoComplete renders a button on hovering over the component, which resets the value. If `clearButton` is set to `false` , the button will not be rendered. - Syntax: ## Examples ### Example 1 ``` import * as React from 'react'; import { AutoComplete } from '@progress/kendo-react-dropdowns'; const browsers = ['Chrome', 'Firefox']; export default function App() { return ; } ``` Provide descriptions and indicate the expected input for TextBoxes, NumericTextBoxes, or MaskedTextBoxes. On every user modification of the input value, the AutoComplete triggers an onChange event. The event argument contains the typed string value that you can use to filter the source. ExampleView SourceEdit inChange ThemeThemeDefaultLoading ... To filter the data after a delay, use a similar implementation. You can toggle the loading property and provide the user with a visual indication of the filtering process. Form Inputs—Input, TextBox, MaskedTextBox, RadioButton, RadioGroup Labels—Label, Floating Label, Hint, Error Popup ## Available ReactComponent enum values: ActionSheet, AIPrompt, Animation, AppBar, ArcGauge, AutoComplete, Avatar, Badge, Barcode, BottomNavigation, Breadcrumb, Button, ButtonGroup, Calendar, Card, Chart, ChartWizard, Chat, Checkbox, Chip, ChipList, ChunkProgressBar, CircularGauge, ColorGradient, ColorPalette, ColorPicker, ComboBox, ContextMenu, ConversationalUI, DataGrid, Grid, DataQuery, DateMath, DateInput, DatePicker, DateRangePicker, DateTimePicker, Dialog, Drag&Drop, Drawer, Drawing, DropDownButton, DropDownList, DropDownTree, Editor, Error, ExcelExport, ExpansionPanel, ExternalDropZone, FileSaver, FileManager, Filter, FlatColorPicker, FloatingActionButton, FloatingLabel, FontIcon, Form, Gantt, Gauge, General, GridLayout, Hint, InlineAIPrompt, Input, Label, LinearGauge, ListBox, ListView, Loader, Map, MaskedTextBox, Menu, MultiColumnComboBox, MultiSelect, MultiSelectTree, MultiViewCalendar, Notification, NumericTextBox, OrgChart, PageTemplates/BuildingBlocks, Pager, PanelBar, PDFProcessing, PDFViewer, PivotGrid, Popover, Popup, ProgressBar, QRCode, RadialGauge, RadioButton, RadioGroup, RangeSlider, Rating, Ripple, Sankey, Scheduler, ScrollView, Signature, Skeleton, Slider, Sortable, Sparkline, SpeechToTextButton, SplitButton, Splitter, Spreadsheet, StackLayout, Stepper, StockChart, SVGIcon, Switch, TabStrip, TaskBoard, TextArea, TextBox, TileLayout, Timeline, TimePicker, Toolbar, Tooltip, TreeList, TreeView, Typography, Upload, VSCodeExtension, Window ## Rules When generating code, explanations, or refactorings, always follow these rules: 1. Component Awareness Whenever a component name is mentioned—regardless of how it's written (all lowercase, all uppercase, mixed case, separate words, or even with typos)—you should always look up the correct example from the corresponding component. Key points: - Match component names case-insensitively and robustly to minor variations - If someone refers to a component (e.g., "button", "BUTTON", "BuTtOn"), match it to the correct component (Button) - After matching, use the example or information associated with that component - The matching should be case-insensitive and robust to minor variations Example: If someone asks about "grid", "GRID", or "GrId", you always refer to DataGrid for the example. Gotcha: Don't just use the word as given—always normalize it and check the component to avoid mistakes or mismatches. 2. Links Awareness When providing links or references to documentation, always use links from the https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain. Avoid using slug syntax like { slug overview } or any placeholder syntax. Instead, provide complete, direct URLs that users can immediately navigate to. Key points: - Use only https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui domain for Kendo React UI documentation links - Provide complete URLs, not slug placeholders - Ensure links are directly accessible and functional - Avoid any template or placeholder syntax in URLs Example: ✅ Correct: https://www.telerik.com/kendo-react-ui/components/grid/ ❌ Incorrect: { slug overview } or /components/{component-name}/overview 3. Editor Tools Awareness For Editor component cases, always use the proper EditorTools import structure and never define tools as strings. Import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' and destructure the individual tools from EditorTools. Required pattern: ```jsx import { Editor, EditorTools } from '@progress/kendo-react-editor'; const { Bold, Italic, Underline, Strikethrough, Subscript, Superscript, ForeColor, BackColor, CleanFormatting, AlignLeft, AlignCenter, AlignRight, AlignJustify, Indent, Outdent, OrderedList, UnorderedList, NumberedList, BulletedList, Undo, Redo, FontSize, FontName, FormatBlock, Link, Unlink, InsertImage, ViewHtml, InsertTable, InsertFile, SelectAll, Print, Pdf, TableProperties, TableCellProperties, AddRowBefore, AddRowAfter, AddColumnBefore, AddColumnAfter, DeleteRow, DeleteColumn, DeleteTable, MergeCells, SplitCell } = EditorTools; ``` Key points: - Always import both Editor and EditorTools from '@progress/kendo-react-editor' - Destructure individual tools from EditorTools object - Use the destructured tool references directly in the tools array - Never define tools as strings (e.g., 'bold', 'italic') - Group related tools in sub-arrays for better organization Example: ✅ Correct: tools={[[Bold, Italic, Underline], [AlignLeft, AlignCenter]]} ❌ Incorrect: tools={[['bold', 'italic', 'underline'], ['alignLeft', 'alignCenter']]} 4. DataGrid Deprecated Properties Awareness For DataGrid component cases, avoid using deprecated properties and always use their modern replacements. The following properties are deprecated and should not be used: Deprecated properties and their modern replacements: - selectedField → use the select state property - editField → use the edit state property - expandedField → use the detailExpand state property - onExpandChange → use onDetailExpandChange for detail-row expansion or onGroupExpandChange for group expansion - cellRender → use the cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - rowRender → use the rows={{ data: CustomRow }} prop - filterCellRender → use the cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - headerCellRender → use the cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.cell → use the column.cells={{ data: CustomCell }} prop - column.headerCell → use the column.cells={{ headerCell: CustomHeaderCell }} prop - column.filterCell → use the column.cells={{ filterCell: CustomCell }} prop - column.footerCell → use the column.cells={{ footerCell: CustomFooterCell }} prop Additional modern updates: - Input component in Column Menu Filter has been replaced with Textbox - scrollable prop now defaults to virtual - Virtual scrolling no longer applies height by default Key points: - Never suggest or use these deprecated properties in DataGrid examples - Always provide modern alternatives when users ask about these properties - Explain that these properties are deprecated and provide the specific modern replacement - Focus on current DataGrid API patterns using state properties and cells/rows props Example: ❌ Deprecated: selectedField="isSelected" editField="inEdit" ✅ Modern: Use select and edit state properties with proper configuration

## API Reference Item
- Name: MultiSelectProps.tags
- Type: Property
- Summary: Sets the tags of the MultiSelect ([see example]({% slug customtags_multiselect %})).
- Syntax: 

## Examples
### Example 1
```
import * as React from 'react';
import { MultiSelect, MultiSelectChangeEvent } from '@progress/kendo-react-dropdowns';

export default function App() {
    const data = ['Tag 1', 'Tag 2', 'Tag 3'];
    const [value, setValue] = React.useState<string[]>(['Orange', 'Apple']);

    const handleChange = (event: MultiSelectChangeEvent) => {
        setValue(event.value);
    };
    return (
        <MultiSelect
            data={data}
            value={value}
            onChange={handleChange}
            tags={value.length > 0 ? [{ text: `${value.length} items selected`, data: [...value] }] : []}
        />
    );
}

```


## API Reference Item
- Name: MultiSelectProps.allowCustom
- Type: Property
- Summary: Specifies whether the MultiSelect allows user-defined values that are not present in the dataset ([see example]({% slug custom_values_multiselect %})). Defaults to 
`false`
.
- Syntax: 

## Examples
### Example 1
```
import * as React from 'react';
import { MultiSelect } from '@progress/kendo-react-dropdowns';

export default function App() {
    const data = ['Item 1', 'Item 2', 'Item 3'];
    return <MultiSelect data={data} allowCustom={true} />;
}

```
